course.subject: ELEC
course.name: Honors Probability and Random Processes in Engineering
course.description: This course is an accelerated and intensive course on probability and random processes. There will be an introduction to statistical inference and random processes in electrical engineering, including the necessary probabilistic background. The course also covers random variables, distribution and density functions, characteristic functions, conditional statistics, expectation, moments, stochastic processes.
course.prerequisites: Grade A- or above in MATH 1014 OR MATH 1018 OR MATH 1020 OR MATH 1024
course.corequisites: MATH 2011 OR MATH 2023
course.exclusions: ELEC 2600, MATH 2421

reviews.author: Aye
reviews.comment_content:
The differences between ELEC2600 and ELEC2600H are located in the last two parts
Part I: Basic Probability Theory
Lecture 1: Course Introduction, Probability Models
Lecture 2: Random Experiments and Probability Axioms
Out-of-Class Reading: Set Operations
Lecture 3: Conditional Probability & Independence
Out-of-Class Reading: Counting Methods
Lecture 4: Sequential Experiments

Part II: Single Random Variables
Lecture 5: Discrete Random Variables, Expected Value and Moments
Lecture 6: Conditional Mean and Important Discrete Random Variables
Out-of-Class Reading: Conditional PMF
Lecture 7: Continuous Random Variables, CDF, PDF
Lecture 8: Expectation of Continuous Random Variables
Lecture 9: Function of a Random Variable

Part III: Multiple Random Variables
Lecture 10: Pairs of Discrete Random Variable
Lecture 11: Pairs of Continuous Random Variable
Lecture 12: Independence, Joint Moments
Lecture 13: Conditional Probability, Conditional Expectation
Lecture 14: Function of 2 Random Variables
Lecture 15: Multiple Random Variable and Expectation

(Be careful of the formula in L16 and remember to write it on the cheat sheet. It was tested this time)

Lecture 18: Central Limit Theorem and Characteristic Function

Part IV: Stochastic Process
Lecture 20: Definition of a Random Process
Lecture 21: Mean and Autocorrelation of Random Process
Lecture 22: Discrete Time Random Process
Lecture 23: Continuous Time Random Process
Lecture 24: Stationary Random Process, Ergodic Process
reviews.comment_teaching: Australian English. Fluent speaking. Teaching is kind of fast. Provide extra materials (such as his research) and promote his PG course (ELEC 6910H - Random Matrix Theory and Applications (3 units)) during class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading:
• Homework (20%) More problems which involve unique materials learnt
• Mid-Term (35%) Same as ELEC2600. One-sided cheat sheet
• Final (45%) Some problems are different from ELEC2600. Two-sided cheat sheet

Guarantee at least the same grade as ELEC2600 with the same total mark.
(e.g. If 90% refer to A in ELEC2600, you will get A or A+ with 90% in ELEC2600H)
reviews.comment_workload: A little larger than ELEC2600 --- mainly because of the extra questions in homeworks.

reviews.author: cdllab
reviews.title: Worth taking!
reviews.comment_content:
Basic concepts of probability theory required to understand in probability models used in engineering and techniques required to develop probability models.
Topics covered:
1. Basic Probability Theory
2. Single Random Variables
3. Multiple Random Variables
4. Stochastic Processes
(Roughly the same as ELEC2600.)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Shi tends to write everything on the white board and explain at the same time so I would say the speed and pace is quite friendly and not hard to catch up with the important points. Though most examples and concepts he mentions appear in the PPT posted before classes, his writing on board helps me build a clear framework and see links between different points. He also shows detailed computation and proof which is a great help to understand how the concepts work and remember them firmly. Examples shown via Jupyter Notebook aids intuitive understanding and can help you with the multiple choices in exams. He also encourages questions and interaction in class. It was noteworthy that listening to Bert's speaking English is enjoyable ;p

Instruction assistant Zhang Xuning is one of the best TAs I met. She is kind and ready to answer questions. The tutorials are also worth to attend because she tends to mention some useful techniques that aids the computation or common errors that may ease the pain of exams. Other TAs are also responsible and friendly.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quite nice.

Grading scheme:
10% 4 HWs
35% midterm
55% final

As far as I know, an overall of 94.65 can get A+ and some of my classmates who obtained an overall of 87/88 got an A.
reviews.comment_workload: Might be a little bit heavier than ELEC2600 since honor version has 1~2 additional advanced questions in each HW. And there are a few additional questions in exams. Each homework has aroud 6 computational questions and 1 coding problem to be done via Jupytor Notebook which can be time consuming but refering to step-by-step hints can help you handle it. Plus there are only four homework sets during the semester so I think the workload is fine. Both exams are close book exams but you are provided with detailed formula sheet and the exam questions are very similar to those in homework. Therefore if you have to be at least familiar with techniques and concepts used in homework to deal with exams.

reviews.author: J Yang
reviews.title: Everyone should take this course if pre-requisite is met
reviews.comment_content:
Probability taught in engineering background. Topics include the following:
1. Basic Probability Theory
2. Single Random Variables
3. Multiple Random Variables
4. Stochastic Process
Intimidating as the topics seem, the content and computation is quite straightforward. In fact, the content is exactly the same as the ELEC2600 normal course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professer Mckay tries his best to interpret probability theory in a basic level. He adopts a screen-share writing way of teaching. Although the writing is somewhat confusing if you fails to keep up with the lecture, the speed and pace is adequately friendly for most students.
It is worth noting that you can stop the professor anytime you want if you are confused. It is highly encouraged by the professor and teaching assistant cause they want everyone to understand what they are teaching by lecture time.
reviews.comment_grading:
Great! Very few non-curved classes in HKUST.

Grading scheme:
2% attendance
8% 5 homeworks
3*15% + 5% 3 highest of 4 quizzes + 1 lowest of 4 quiz
40% final

Obtained an overall score of higher than 90, you are guaranteed with an A+. And as far as I know, some of my classmates who obatained an overall 87/88 are also granted with an A+. Unlike the ELEC2600 where everything is curved, this course does not compete with other candidates. The exact reason why I encourage everyone to give it a shot.
reviews.comment_workload:
A little bit heavier than ELEC2600.

Differences are that in honor class, there exists more problems, which are significantly more challenging, in homework, quiz, and even final exam. But that's all.

You are encouraged to work with others when doing homework so no need to worry too much. I personally spent about 1 day or so doing each homework set, 2 days preparing each quiz, and 3 days for the final exam.

I have upload the first part of the course if you are interested in what it teaches.

reviews.author: 赵欣然
reviews.comment_content: Basic knowledge about probability and some of his work. However, statistic material was not covered at all. The course ended with the random process.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very explicit. The class was very small. So there was much communication between the professor and us.
reviews.comment_grading: Absolute grading, easy to get A or above. I personally got 95%, which was not hard if you could get a full mark in homework and midterm.
reviews.comment_workload: Very light. There are only 4 assignments and I spent about 3 hours on each. The tutorial covered some relevant problems but you can just ignore them if you wanted to have your dinner earlier.
